div1.p: Carter plans on working on the book as long as she is needed and then she is considering entering the hospital in order to fully regain her health.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 11, 1920
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
October 11, 1930.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
I hope that my reply to your inquiry about my health (when I
called you up just now re the Bibliography) will not give you a false
impression. I am able, and most anxious! to do anything that re-
mains to be done on the book by Miss Brown and myself, up to the time
that it is actually completed. After that, if Carter Redd can in any
way arrange the financial side, I think I should go to hospital in
the hope that life, physically, can be marde more endurable for the
future. I had made up my mind after my, most beneficial stay in the
Hopkins in 1928, that I could never again afford its repetition, un-
less my doing so were essential to the work. This it is not, but, if
I do not improve it will be utterly unfair for Miss Brown to have an
invalid (or semi-invalid) on her hands during the time I had hoped
that our “combining forces” would make life easier for her.

I can have no words save those of gratitude to Fate at the
present moment, still...I wish that she could have had enough appreciation
of the eternal fitness of things to have at least postponed [unclear]
this last physical “unpleasantness” and have let me “give thanks” in
peace. Still...“It is a good thing to give thanks!”...and the Lord
knows I do!

closer.seg:
P. S. Muchlove to “the Susans.”
P. P. S. Have just found the
concluding pages of
your analysis of the
Contents of the “Early History of Yellow Fever...i. e.
Pages x and xi. These I erroneously reported as miss-
ing, in my letter of last night. These Contents are
a great addition to the book!
L. A. C.
